page.title: 15WIGBER LOW NAME/LOCATION
page.content: {WIG}- probably from the name WICGA {BER}-derived from BEORG, a "barrow" {LOW}-from the word HLAW, a "mound" This feature lies about two kilometres SSW of Bradbourne. It is part of a north/south ridge of Carboniferous Limestone about 10-15 metres across, with steep slopes falling away on 3 sides. Although not the highest hill in the area, it is possible to see the Trent Valley to the south on a clear day, while views east and north extend to about 7 kilometres. The{flat topped stone platform}was used for exposed corpses prior to burial in the{New Stone Age}and{Bronze {Age.} The visibility of the exposed site meant that carrion birds were plentiful. Burial or cremation followed such exposure.
